Catalytic conversion of the atmospheric CO2 to essential chemicals such as fuels and industrial feeds has become a subject of much interest due to its potential to meet sustainable global commodity and energy demands from a presumably environmental threats. Among the suitable catalysts for the multidimensional processes involved in the conversion, diphosphine ligands and their molecular analogues have been widely explored, and their potential for such responses is remarkable. Thus, this review surveys the reports on structure-related catalytic performances of various molecular analogues of diphosphine ligands in the conversion of CO2 into other chemical utilities. The analogues have been documented in various molecular forms, such as small molecules, dimerised hybrids. Ferrocenes and in complexes with metals such as nickel, cobalt, rhodium, rhenium, and iridium. The highlighted derivatives, such as DL01-DL14, display good enantioselectivity and hydricity that support catalytic effects on the hydrogenation of CO2 and other organocompounds. They reportedly demonstrate interesting potential to produce green fuels, chemical building blocks, and industrial feedstock such as carboxylic acids and carboxylates (e.g. formic acid, formate, acetic acid), alcohols (e.g. methanol, ethanol), ketones and ketoesters, olefins and hydrocarbon fuels. In addition, some of the diphosphine chemical analogues are also applicable for other similar processes, such as the hydrogenation of α- and β-ketones, acetophenone, functionalized olefins such as enamides, ethyl acetamidocinnamate, and itaconates. This overview promotes the applicability of diphosphine analogues as viable catalysts for converting CO2 into other chemical utilities amenable to further scientific efforts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Diphosphine ligands Catalysis Enantioselectivity and hydricity Clean fuels Industrial feedstock Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The increasing rate of carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from human activities has become a global concern due to its unpleasant effects on the global environment. Some obnoxious consequences of CO2 emission and concentration on the environment include global warming, acidic rainfall, ocean acidification, air pollution, and climate change [1]. Therefore, the need to convert the CO2 in the atmosphere from a potential threat to usable chemicals has taken on interesting scientific dimensions. By this, CO2, which contains the highest oxidation state of carbon, is reduced by green hydrogen via CO2 hydrogenation into chemical utilities. The process is a highly promising and widely explored chemical reaction due to its applicability for the production of clean and energy-rich fuels, as well as industrial feedstocks such as alcohols and hydrocarbons. Other essential products of CO2 hydrogenation include carbon monoxide (CO), methane (CH4), methanol (CH3OH), formic acid (HCOOH)/formate (HCOO-) and C2+ chemicals including acetic acid, ethanol, higher alcohols, benzene, olefins, and anticipatedly, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and some other long chain hydrocarbons, commonly human and industrial utilities [2–6]. Through the process of CO2 hydrogenation, the global challenge of fossil fuel depletion and hydrogen storage could be ameliorated, whilst useful liquid fuels are being produced [7–9]. In addition, the multidimensional catalytic conversion process represents a Green energy source and portrays a strategy for mitigating the effects of the inevitable increased anthropogenic CO2 concentration. Undesired natural phenomena such as global warming, acidic rainfall, ocean acidification, and other likely environmental hazards associated with the release of CO2 to the atmosphere, primarily from the combustion of fossil fuels, have been suppressed through the conversion. Again, CO2 is widely available, cheap, and represents a renewable source of carbon and an efficient pathway to carbon neutrality [10–13,5]. These advantages further underscore the essentiality of CO2 hydrogenation for global socioeconomic development. Moreover, CO2 hydrogenation in all forms demonstrates the transformation of wastes into sustainable fuels and other useful chemical feedstock [14,15]. For instance, both C1 and C2+ molecules produced from the process, including carbon monoxide (CO), methane, methanol, methanoic acid, and its methanoate (formate) derivatives, ethanol, and acetic acid, are essential industrial feedstocks and fuels, and are mostly produced in bulk [5]. Gorbunov and co-workers recently reported an overview of information on the reduction of CO2 by H2 in the presence of catalysts to produce industrial fuels and feedstocks such as formic acid, methanol, olefins, other alcohols, and epoxides [16]. The carbon-neutral hydrogenation of CO2 to produce LPG and olefins assures a brighter future of green energy production [3,17], thereby becoming increasingly attractive worldwide. These indicate that CO2 has the potential to be transformed into industrial utilities, further supporting the science of turning waste into wealth. As such, the process has attracted increasing scientific interest in recent decades. 2 The process of CO2 hydrogenation: Opportunities and challenges The CO2 hydrogenation fixation mostly occurs via electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, thermocatalysis, photothermal catalysis [2,5], methanol intermediate formation, or through the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) [13,18]. These processes necessarily involve the use of catalysts for lowering the high energy required for activating the CO2 and dissociating H2 molecules in most cases [19,20]. Sometimes, the required H2 molecules for the reaction are obtained by splitting water molecules under the influence of a renewable electricity source, such as solar energy [5], and catalysts. Ideal catalysts for the process are characterised by high purity, stability, efficiency under mild conditions, ease of handling, and enantioselectivity. These are mostly favoured by homogeneous catalysis, with other advantages such as high reactivity, easier characterisation, tunable catalytic activity, clearer reaction mechanisms at the molecular levels, controllable reaction pathways, ideal for efficient chemical transformations, especially for energy production, although recoverability remains a major challenge [21]. The common molecular catalysts for the asymmetric hydrogenation process are functionally designed through the modifications of the chiral ligands, mostly in coordination to suitable metal precursors [19,20]. Typically, they function by activating molecular H2 to form H + ions, which are subsequently transferred to the substrate [22]. The hydride transfer process is the most critical step in the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation in homogeneous conditions [23]. Considering these factors, diphosphine ligands have been reported to be suitable as catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation due to their molecular structures, as detailed in subsequent sections. The summary of the products (fuels and industrial feedstock) from the diphosphine-facilitated catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 and other organocompounds is illustrated in Fig. 1 . 3 Analogues of diphosphine ligands: Simple small molecules, hybrids, and metal complexes 3.1 Small molecules and hybrids Diphosphine ligands in various chemical forms have been reported to demonstrate excellent catalytic effects on asymmetric hydrogenation reactions [24]. A recent report has indicated that important factors that affect the mechanistic chemistry and utility of diphosphine analogues as catalysts include catalyst composition and structure, and external conditions. These have a significant influence on the product selectivity during the CO2 hydrogenation [25]. Among the most common diphosphine ligands used in catalytic reactions, (S)-(2,3,6′,7′-tetrahydro-[1,1′-binaphthalene]−7,7′-diyl)bis(diphenylphosphane) (BINAP), ((2S,7′S)-2,2′-dimethoxy-2,3,6′,7′-tetrahydro-[1,1′-binaphthalene]−7,7′-diyl)bis(diphenylphosphane) (MeO-BIPHEP), 4,4′-bis(diphenylphosphaneyl)-2,2′,6,6′-tetramethoxy-3,3′-bipyridine (P-Phos), (9,9-dimethyl-9H-xanthene-4,5-diyl)bis(diphenylphosphane) (Xantphos), (5aS,8aS)-1,13-bis(diphenylphosphaneyl)-5a,6,7,8,8a,9-hexahydro-5H-chromeno[3,2-d]xanthene (SKP ligand), (4,4,4′,4′,6,6′-hexamethyl-2,2′-spirobi[chromane]−8,8′-diyl)bis(diphenylphosphane) (SPANphos) and 7,7′-bis(diphenylphosphaneyl)-2,2′,3,3′-tetrahydro-1,1′-spirobi[indene] [(R)-SDP] (Fig. 2 ) are widely known. They are mostly used in metal-catalyzed asymmetric reactions such as hydrogenation and hydrosilylation mainly due to their impressive enantioselectively [26,27]. Due to the impressive performance of these diphosphine ligands in the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation, several other new analogues have been derivatised. For instance, Bing and co-workers synthesized two imidazolium-based diphosphine ligands, 3-(2-((3R,4R)-3,4-bis(diphenylphosphaneyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-2-oxoethyl)-1-methyl-1H-imidazol-3-ium chloride (DL01) and 3-(2-((3R,4R)-3,4-bis(diphenylphosphaneyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-2-oxoethyl)-1-methyl-1H-imidazol-3-ium tetrafluoroborate (DL02) (Fig. 3 ), and assessed their applicability for asymmetric hydrogenation. They reported that the ligands show a good catalytic potential with high enantioselectivity relevant to CO2 hydrogenation [28]. In hybrid forms, the performance of diphosphine ligands for catalytic hydrogenation generally appears to be enhanced. This was indicated when Steiner and his research associates evaluated the efficiency of some chiral biaryl diphosphine ligands, BIPHEP and MeO-BIPHEP, in hybrid forms with silica gel (SiO2) in an unprecedented study. Their results showed that when supported by the SiO2, their enantioselectivity during asymmetric hydrogenation of phenylglyoxylate (V) was similar or became slightly enhanced [29], supporting their suitability for the hydrogenation process even in hybrid forms. In another investigation by Lilio et al., the catalytic activities of Rh-diphosphine complexes were reportedly enhanced when a non-pendant amine base such as 2,8,9-triisopropyl-2,5,8,9-tetraaza-1-phosphabicyclo[3,3,3]- undecane (Verkade’s base) was incorporated into it, although the hydricities were similar [30]. According to a report by Walsh and co-workers, bioinspired diphosphine catalysts consisting of amino acids such as aspartic acid, glycine, histidine, and leucine incorporated into the second and outer coordination spheres of Rh(bis)diphosphine complexes have shown an altered catalytic effect on CO2 hydrogenation when compared to their analogous phenyl-substituted counterparts [31]. Although the incorporation of biferrocene into some triphosphine Walphos ligands (SL-W001 and SL-W002) did not positively enhance the catalytic asymmetric hydrogenation of alkenes and ketones [32]. This could be traced to the additional phenyl groups, which may likely induce stearic hindrance associated with triphosphine ligands compared to the diphosphine counterparts. The shreds of evidence show that incorporation of other chemical moieties into diphosphines to form hybrids may contribute positively to their catalytic performance. 3.2 Metal complexes Synthesis of metal complexes of diphosphines has attracted scientific interest owing to their essential utilities in medicinal applications, energy conversion, and catalysis, including catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 [33]. Metal complexes of phosphines are commonly applied in the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2, taking advantage of the transformation of metal-hydride to CO2, which is the most important reaction based on their kinetic barrier of the hydride transfer (TS) and thermodynamic hydricity ( Δ G H − 0 ) [10,23]. In most cases, the identity of the reductant determines the mechanisms of CO2 hydrogenation/reduction. This is evident from the study by Buss and co-workers on low-valent molybdenum complexes of para-tertphenyl diphosphine, which was shown to yield CO2 reduction via CO2 hydrosilylation [34]. As such, several metals have been coordinated to form complexes with diphosphine ligands and have been explored in catalytic CO2 hydrogenation. 3.3 Palladium-diphosphine complexes Palladium complexes of diphosphine ligands have been reported as promising catalysts in organic synthesis [35], even in bulky forms. Relevantly, their influence on CO2 has been remarkable. Devi in 2019 synthesised some Pd(II) complexes of diphosphine ligands, PNHP[HN(CH2CH2PPh2)2] and PP2[PhP(CH2CH2PPh2)2], and evaluated their potential to induce the activation of H2 and reduction of CO2 via the metal-ligand coordination as alternatives to molecular catalysts. The study showed that the complexes contain a hydride relay that could rotate freely, making them as functional as the biological NADH for reducing unsaturated substrates such as aldehydes and ketones [22]. 3.4 Ruthenium-diphosphine complexes Ruthenium complexes with bidentate diphosphine ligands such as 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane (dppe) have shown outstanding performance in CO₂ hydrogenation. These complexes are known for their robust activity and ability to stabilise the active catalytic species throughout the cycle. For instance, four phosphine-free ruthenium NCN-ligand complexes (Fig. 4 ) reported by Sung et al. exhibit considerable efficacy in formic acid production even under low-pressure hydrogenation conditions [36]. 3.5 Cobalt-diphosphine complexes Recent advancements have highlighted cobalt as a promising non-precious metal alternative. Cobalt-diphosphine complexes operate through CO(I)/CO(II) or CO(-I)/CO(I) redox cycles, effectively catalysing the hydrogenation of CO₂ to formate, particularly under aqueous or buffered conditions [37,38]. Yao et al. [38] developed cobalt(I) pincer complexes coordinated by diphosphine-type ligands that demonstrated high turnover numbers and recyclability in aqueous systems [38]. The effects of the cobalt-based diphosphine complexes on the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to produce other chemicals are illustrated in later parts. 3.6 Nickel complexes Nickel-based catalysts are another class of non-noble metal systems that have been computationally studied for their capacity to activate and hydrogenate CO₂. Mahato et al. [39] employed density functional theory (DFT) calculations to design diphosphine-supported nickel complexes, revealing favourable energetics for CO₂ binding and hydrogen splitting under ambient conditions. The proposed catalytic cycle/mechanism for this process is summarily illustrated by the authors as shown below (Scheme 1 ) [39]. Biswas et al. also reported the impressive performance of some Ni-hydride complexes of multidentate phosphines, including diphosphines, on hydride transfer barrier, favouring the NiP2N2 complex (Fig. 5 ) with a much lower hydride transfer barrier. Their computational studies revealed that the Ni(II) complex with a quarterdentate ligand (NiP2N2) showed much higher potential for CO2 hydrogenation in aqueous medium than the free bidentate diphosphine ligand [23]. 4 Physicochemical properties of diphosphine analogues as potential catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation Catalytic efficiency remains a challenge in the recycling of CO2 and conservation of H2 through useful processes such as CO2 hydrogenation. The structural features, electronic effects, and general chemistry of diphosphine ligands strongly support catalytic potential during CO2 hydrogenation. For instance, a study has shown that the presence of strong sigma (σ) electron-withdrawing group(s) on diphosphine ligands in catalysts enhances hydricity of the dihydride complex formed by lowering the activation energy for breaking the H2 molecules and activating the CO2 group [40]. The distinctive structural and stereochemistry of phosphorus are crucial for the development of steroselective phosphorus ligands such as the diphosphines [41], which are renowned chirogenic and electron-rich compounds used in catalyses [42]. Naturally, some physiological stimuli possess the ability to modulate the catalysis of some diphosphine-based catalysts, such as rhodium-diphosphine. Using the catalyst, the hydricity and rates of hydride complex formation were reportedly altered when a photoswitching material, such as azobenzene. Incorporating it into Rh(bis)diphosphine catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation caused photo-induced structural changes, which modulate the resultant catalytic process as observed by Priyadarshani and co-researchers [43]. The performance of diphosphine in catalysis is also dictated by structural frameworks and contributions to enantioselectivity [44]. A study by van den Broeke and co-workers also indicates that the catalytic activities of rhodium-diphosphine complexes on the hydrogenation process could be influenced by anion-cation separation in their molecular skeletons. The scientists demonstrated the impact of highly fluorous tetraphenylborate anions in enhancing the catalytic activities of rhodium-diphosphine complexes in the hydrogenation of 1-octene in acetone in both conventional and fluorous media [45]. 5 Applications of diphosphine analogues as potential catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation Catalysts that are commonly applied in CO2/CO reduction, especially through the electrochemical reduction, are metal-based, such as Au, Ag, Cd, Cu, Fe, Hg, Pd, Sn, and Zn catalysts [46–48]. Among organic compounds, suitable catalysts for the multidimensional processes involved in the CO2 hydrogenation include diphosphine ligands and their molecular analogues. The analogues have been documented in various molecular forms, such as small molecules, dimerised hybrids. Ferrocenes and in complexes with metals such as nickel, cobalt, rhodium, rhenium, and iridium. They have been widely explored, and their potential for such CO2 reduction via the hydrogenation process is remarkable. An overview by Crepy and Imamoto has revealed that diphosphine-based chiral ligands in complexes with some coordinating metals, such as rhodium and ruthenium, are extensively utilised in asymmetric hydrogenation catalytic processes, due to their ability to induce high reaction rates and interesting enantioselectivity when the reaction conditions are optimised [42]. Sometimes, diphosphine ligands are used in capping metallic materials to form nanoparticles, which are subsequently used as catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. This was demonstrated by Fernandez-Martinez and Godard when they investigated the potential of a diphosphine(dppe)-capped Pd nanoparticles for the production of formates from CO2 hydrogenation. Although the results of their analyses favoured phosphine (PPh3) as a better stabilising capping agent over dppe [49]. However, the study indicates that diphosphines can be applied as capping and stabilising agents in preparing metallic nanoparticles for catalytic hydrogenation of CO2. These buttress the proficiency of diphosphine ligands in various chemical formulations for the catalytic activities. Some of the chemical footprints and essential products of such hydrogenation processes are highlighted below. 6 Formic acid and other carboxylic acids production The hydrogenation of carbon dioxide (CO₂) into valuable chemicals such as formic acid (HCOOH) and other carboxylic acids has emerged as an essential strategy in addressing environmental challenges related to greenhouse gas emissions. This reaction not only facilitates the conversion of a major pollutant into chemical feedstocks but also provides a pathway for sustainable and reversible hydrogen storage in the form of safe and stable chemicals. It also promotes the pathways for viable economies devoid of fossil fuels [50,51,36]. The reaction is usually facilitated by the actions of catalysts, which lower the energy barrier for efficient dissociation of the molecular H2 into Hδ+ and Hδ- species [52]. A theoretical study on the mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation to form formate indicated that the formation of the dihydride complex is preceded by H2 oxidative addition to the metal ion centre of the complex, and progresses by the hydride abstraction through a nucleophilic attack from an external base. The mechanistic process terminates by a second hydride abstraction, this time through a nucleophilic attack on the CO2 to induce the release of formate and a protonated base (Eq. (1)) [40]. (1) CO2 + H2 + Base → HCOO- + [HBase]+ Among the various catalytic systems developed, metal complexes coordinated by diphosphine ligands have demonstrated remarkable efficiency and tunability in the catalytic hydrogenation of CO₂ to carboxylic acids [36], although the stability and efficiency of such catalysts sometimes depend on the chemical nature of the base [53]. According to a recent report by Ganley and co-workers, one of the major challenges with heterogeneous metal-based catalysts such as diphosphine-metal complexes is their proneness to catalyst poisoning likely from impure reagents, reaction media and heterogeneous ligands, especially the Lewis bases. As such, designing a robust chemical route to enhance the performance of such heterogeneous metal-based catalysts may require a good understanding of the possible upstream impurities and their impacts. Suggestively, stronger bases offer more advantages in this regard compared to the weaker ones due to their ideal solubility. Again, solvents with lower heat capacity seem to be worth consideration since they support the stability of the catalysts [54]. This transformation proceeds through a multistep mechanism typically involving metal-hydride intermediates and the insertion of CO₂ into a metal–hydride bond, followed by protonation or reaction with a base to yield formic acid or its salt (formate) (Scheme 2 ) [36]. The hydrogenation of carbon dioxide (CO₂) to carboxylic acids, particularly formic acid, typically proceeds through a multistep catalytic cycle facilitated by diphosphine-ligated metal complexes. This transformation involves three fundamental mechanistic steps: oxidative addition of molecular hydrogen (H₂) to the metal center to generate a dihydride species, insertion of CO₂ into one of the metal–hydride (M–H) bonds to yield a metal–formate intermediate, and subsequent protonolysis or substitution that liberates formic acid or formate and regenerates the active catalyst [39,36]. Beyond formic acid, certain systems enable further transformation into higher carboxylic acids such as acetic acid under more complex conditions, including high pressure or the use of cooperative catalytic systems. For instance, cobalt–Group 13 complexes developed by Vollmer et al. [37] were shown to facilitate partial C–C coupling, resulting in trace acetic acid formation [37]. Similarly, Buffered ruthenium diphosphine complexes selectively yielded both formic and acetic acids, with ligand architecture playing a crucial role in directing catalytic selectivity. Diphosphine ligands are particularly advantageous in these reactions due to their bidentate chelation, which imparts enhanced stability to metal hydride and formate intermediates, allows fine-tuning of redox properties, and improves both product selectivity and catalytic turnover frequencies [38]. Recently, Gelman-Trop and co-researchers prepared some iridium complexes bearing amine derivatives, including diphosphine ligands (Scheme 3 ) and evaluated their potential for CO2 hydrogenation under mild conditions to produce formic acid. Their analyses involving quantum calculations and experimental investigation revealed interesting catalytic performance of the complexes, supported quantitatively by a turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF) of up to 6 × 104 and 1.7 × 104, respectively, per hour [50]. These further portray metal-diphosphine complexes as next-generation catalysts for the present and future CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid. 7 Formate and other carboxylate production Formate of cations, such as ammonium formate, has been reported as a good ionic liquid energy carrier for electrochemical systems. It is produced through simple, economical, and green routes involving the reaction of formic acid with ammonia. In addition, ammonium formate can be easily transported and stored due to its solid state under ambient conditions [55]. Formates of potassium and sodium are renowned to be produced at large scales due to their utilities, including as de-icers for pavements and roads. They are energy-dense, safe, non-flammable, non-toxic, easy to store and transport, and highly stable for a long period of years. As such, they are recognised as future green fuels [56]. For instance, the direct formate fuel cells (DFFC) are an example of an emerging chemical energy carrier that converts the stored formate (chemical energy) directly into electricity. It has attracted scientific attention in recent years mainly as a form of carbon-neutral fuel, utilizer, and economical membrane and electrocatalytic materials requirements [57]. Therefore, the catalytic conversion of the atmospheric CO2 into essential fuels such as formates using carbon-neutral energy has become highly interesting to the catalysis and material science communities. Recent scientific developments have captured the application of diphosphine-metal complexes to speed up the rates of hydrogenation of CO2 to formates. The catalytic cycle for the process is illustrated in Scheme 4 [58–60]. Burgess and his co-researchers specifically prepared a Ni complex of bis(diphosphine) of the type [NiL2](BF4)2 and its corresponding hydride, [HNiL2]BF4 (where L = 1,2-[bis(dimethoxypropyl)phosphino]ethane) for CO2 hydrogenation to produce formate (HCOO-). The hydricity ( Δ G H − 0 ) of the HNiL2 + in aqueous solution was reported as 23.2(3) kcal/mol, while that of the resultant formate was found to be 24.1 kcal/mol, with a difference of up to 1 kcal/mol, indicating that the hydride transfer from HNiL2 +to CO2 to yield formate was favourable (Scheme 5 ). The maximum turnover frequency of [4.0(5)] × 10–1 h-1 was recorded at 80 °C, 34 atm and 1:1 CO2/H2 mixture. The study demonstrated the potential of the Ni-diphosphine complex, NiL2, of its hydride HNiL2 + to catalyse CO2 hydrogenation in aqueous solution in the presence of NaHCO3 as a readily available basic additive [58]. The catalytic hydrogenation of carbon dioxide (CO₂) to formate represents a viable approach to carbon recycling and green energy storage. This transformation typically proceeds via a mechanism to formic acid production, but in the presence of a base that facilitates deprotonation and stabilises the formate anion [38]. Diphosphine-ligated metal complexes, particularly those involving Ru, Co, Ir, and Mn, are widely recognised for their high activity and selectivity in this process under mild to moderate conditions [8,38]. For instance, cobalt(I) pincer complexes with diphosphine arms have demonstrated remarkable catalytic turnover in aqueous bicarbonate systems, cycling through Co(I)/Co(III) redox states [38]. Similarly, ruthenium–bis(diphosphine) systems sustained high formate productivity and recyclability in buffered environments. Iridium-based complexes bearing imidazoline-derived diphosphine ligands also showed excellent performance, notably under low hydrogen and CO₂ pressures, thus enhancing practical applicability [8]. Mechanistically, the reaction follows the oxidative addition of H₂ to form a metal dihydride, insertion of CO₂ into an M–H bond forming a metal–formate intermediate, and final base-assisted release of the formate product [37]. Beyond formate, other carboxylate derivatives such as acetate and oxalate can be formed via C–C bond coupling or higher-valent intermediates, often requiring more elaborate ligand frameworks. Cobalt–Group 13 complexes have enabled such partial CO₂ coupling to produce acetic acid, which in the presence of base exists predominantly as acetate [37]. Manganese pincer complexes also support reversible formate production from CO₂, underscoring the role of ligand electronic properties in reaction selectivity [38]. Diphosphine ligands contribute significantly to the stability and reactivity of these systems by preventing ligand dissociation, promoting metal-ligand cooperation, and enabling regio- and chemoselective transformations. Tuning their bite angles and donor strengths has proven crucial in modulating selectivity between formate and formic acid production [61]. The high energy demand, sustainable green fuels, and reduction of CO2 emissions have become a driving force for the development of efficient catalysts such as Ruthenium bis(diphosphine) complexes for CO2 hydrogenation, as reported by Galan et al. in 2023. Their operando mechanistic evaluation of the catalytic effects in the presence of bases to yield formate indicated the vital effects of the base on the reversibility and catalytic rates of the CO2 transformation. The study underscores the consideration of base selection in the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to formate whilst using metal-diphosphine complexes. The proposed mechanistic study indicated that the catalytic cycle commenced by reacting the Ru-diphosphine-acetate complex with H2 at 18 °C and 20 atm for 20 h in the presence of d8-THF to produce its dihydride analogue. The dihydride complex is then reacted with formic acid to form a chelating formate complex, which is reacted with a strong base to regenerate a protonated Ru-diphosphine dihydride complex, as illustrated below (Scheme 6 ) [62]. Although a report has revealed that ligand modifications can also influence the catalytic performance of Ru-based complexes in such a hydrogenation process [19]. In a study reported by Lilio and co-workers in 2015, some Rh(I) complexes of bis(diphosphine) as well as their corresponding hydride complexes were synthesised and studied for thermodynamic and catalytic effects on CO2 hydrogenation in comparison to the effects shown by [Rh(P2N2)2]+ complexes incorporated with pendant bases. The results of the analyses showed that the nonpendant-amine-containing Rh(I) complex of diphosphine is more catalytically active than [Rh(P2N2)2]+ complexes, although with similar hydricities in the hydrogenation of CO2 to formate [30]. A catalyst composed of iridium complexed with imine-diphosphine ligand has also been reported with high efficiency for CO2 hydrogenation to produce formate, evident by a yield and TON reaching 99 % and 450,000 h-1, respectively. Mechanistic studies suggested that the imine moiety in the diphosphine-based ligand plays a critical role in the catalytic activation of CO2 and cleavage of the H2 molecule [63]. Although some phosphine-free complexes, such as the NCN-ligands in coordination to ruthenium, have also been reported as useful [36], however, the catalytic effects of diphosphine-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to formate remain prominent and are interestingly attracting global attention. 8 Methanol and other alcohol production The catalytic hydrogenation of CO₂ to methanol and higher alcohols is a key transformation in carbon capture and utilisation technology, offering sustainable pathways for producing renewable fuels, industrial feedstocks, and fine chemicals. Unlike the production of formate or formic acid, converting CO₂ to methanol requires complete hydrogenation involving multiple hydride transfer steps. Diphosphine-ligated metal complexes have shown exceptional promise in mediating this transformation due to their ability to stabilise reaction intermediates, control reaction selectivity, and tune the electronic environment of the catalytic metal centre [64,38]. The general reaction for methanol synthesis from CO₂ involves three moles of hydrogen gas to yield one mole of methanol and water. This reaction is thermodynamically and kinetically challenging and requires highly efficient catalysts to minimise side reactions such as CO production. Tang et al. [64] reported that ruthenium complexes coordinated by cyclopentadienone and diphosphine ligands facilitated the selective conversion of CO₂ to methanol under mild conditions. These ligands provided both electronic stabilisation and steric protection to key intermediates, preventing over-reduction to undesired products like methane [64]. The stepwise hydrogenation process proceeds through formate (HCOO⁻), formaldehyde (CH₂O), and ultimately methanol (CH₃OH). Each intermediate must be stabilised and transformed under controlled conditions to ensure high selectivity and efficiency. The initial step involves hydride attack on CO₂ to form formate, followed by two more hydride transfers yielding formaldehyde and eventually methanol upon further hydrogenation [64]. Beyond ruthenium, first-row transition metals such as cobalt and manganese have gained interest due to their earth-abundant and lower cost. Yao et al. computationally studied manganese-pincer complexes supported by diphosphine ligands and demonstrated their potential for methanol synthesis via ligand-assisted electron transfer mechanisms. These findings underline the critical role of ligand design in facilitating complex multi-electron processes involved in methanol generation [38]. Copper-based systems have also been explored for photocatalytic CO₂ reduction to methanol. Yamazaki et al. [65] developed Cu(I)-diphosphine complexes capable of stepwise CO₂ reduction under light irradiation. The diphosphine ligands in these systems played a pivotal role in modulating the electronic environment of the copper centre, enhancing its ability to undergo photochemically driven electron transfer reactions [65]. Beyond methanol, the hydrogenation of CO₂ to higher alcohols such as ethanol and propanol introduces the additional challenge of C–C bond formation. Recent advancements have been made in the design of diphosphine-supported bimetallic cobalt systems capable of promoting such carbon–carbon coupling under high-pressure conditions. Vollmer et al. [37] reported that ligand sterics and electronics were key in influencing the selectivity towards higher alcohols, demonstrating the importance of fine-tuning the diphosphine framework to direct reaction pathways [37]. Diphosphine ligands contribute to alcohol production by offering electronic modulation, steric control, and bifunctional reactivity. They stabilise hydride and carbon-bound intermediates, prevent catalyst deactivation, and enable cooperative metal-ligand mechanisms that are essential for efficient and selective hydrogenation of CO₂ to alcohols. 9 Ketone production Ketones are valuable intermediates in the production of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and fine chemicals. Despite their industrial importance, the catalytic hydrogenation of CO₂ to ketones remains relatively underexplored, especially in comparison to the synthesis of formic acid, methanol, and alcohols. This is primarily due to the additional mechanistic complexity involved in forming C–C bonds from a single-carbon source like CO₂. Recent advances in ligand design, particularly involving diphosphine frameworks, have begun to address these challenges by enabling selective C–C coupling reactions and stabilising key intermediates in ketone formation [66,8]. The general strategy for synthesising ketones from CO₂ typically involves a multi-step process. It begins with the reduction of CO₂ to carbon monoxide or metal-acyl intermediates. These intermediates then undergo C–C bond-forming reactions such as migratory insertion or nucleophilic coupling, ultimately followed by hydrogenation to yield the ketone. For example, a generic pathway might involve a CO₂ molecule reacting with an alkyl-metal species (R–M), coordinated by a diphosphine ligand, forming a metal-acyl intermediate (R–CO–R′), which is then hydrogenated to produce the final ketone product. Such pathways require not only efficient catalytic turnover but also finely tuned ligand environments that can facilitate selective steps in the reaction sequence [65]. Diphosphine-ligated metal complexes are emerging as highly promising catalysts in this area. Gupta et al. [66] synthesised dipyrromethane–diphosphine ligands featuring different meso‑substituents and coordinated them to nickel. These complexes were found to be efficient in the transfer hydrogenation of ketones, demonstrating excellent activity and selectivity. The success of these catalysts was attributed to the electron-rich nature of the diphosphine ligands, which enhanced hydride transfer efficiency, and the meso‑substituents that helped fine-tune the steric and electronic environment around the nickel centre [66]. Beyond nickel, rhodium and iridium complexes have also shown promise. Xu et al. (2019) investigated Cp-Ir systems bearing imidazoline-functionalized diphosphine ligands. These catalysts demonstrated the ability to convert CO₂ into both C₂+ alcohols and ketones under hydrogenation conditions. The diphosphine ligands in these complexes stabilised the Ir centre and facilitated reversible hydrogenation and C–C bond formation with impressive turnover numbers, indicating the robustness and efficiency of the system [8]. Photocatalytic systems have also played a role in ketone formation from CO₂. Yamazaki et al. [65] reported the use of diphosphine-coordinated copper(I) complexes as photocatalysts. These systems, in combination with organoboranes or other nucleophiles, enabled the formation of ketones through light-induced electron transfer and CO₂ coupling reactions under mild conditions. In this context, the diphosphine ligands not only controlled the electronic structure of the copper centre but also promoted charge separation and reactivity essential for multi-electron redox processes [65]. Overall, diphosphine ligands contribute to ketone synthesis by promoting CO₂ activation at low-valent metal centres, facilitating selective C–C bond formation, and stabilising ketonic transition states through bidentate coordination. Their ability to modulate both steric and electronic factors is key to achieving product selectivity and catalytic efficiency. However, despite these advances, challenges remain in maintaining catalytic stability and avoiding over-reduction or diversion to alcohol products. Future efforts are likely to focus on designing pincer-type diphosphines for better regioselectivity, incorporating multimetallic systems to enable cooperative activation, and integrating photoredox or electrochemical drivers to enhance the thermodynamic feasibility of complex CO₂ transformations. 10 Diphosphine ligands in other industrial hydrogenation processes Diphosphine ligands are versatile in several metal-catalysed reactions. Some chiral-bridged atropisomeric diphosphine oxides, DL03, DL04, and DL05 (Fig. 6 ), prepared via multistep approaches involving the diastereoselective Ullmann coupling and diastereomeric ring-closure reactions, were reported to display better enantioselectivity than BINAP and P-Phos when applied for asymmetric hydrogenation of α- and β-ketones to hydroketoesters, essential blocks in organic reactions [26]. In another study, chiral ruthenium complexes of the derivatives of these ligands, including BINAP and MeO-BIPHEP, were reportedly efficient in the asymmetric hydrogenation of β-keto esters at both atmospheric and higher pressures, significantly lowering the catalyst-substrate ratio used. The process is important in the preparation of building blocks for the total synthesis of some pharmaceuticals, including fluoxetine, duloxetine, and corynomycolic acid for academic and industrial applications [67]. The effects of diphosphine ligands in complex with Ru (RuDph1) (Fig. 7 ) have been studied on the catalysis of the hydrogenation of acetophenone to produce R- and S-alcohols used in industries. In the study, Chen and co-workers noted that the two methyl groups at the meta positions of the ligands are critical for the distinctive activation energy observed for the reaction pathways concerning the alcohols and for the subsequent highly enantioselective hydrogenation [44]. Barbato et al. also successfully synthesised osmium complexes of some chiral diphosphine ligands from a precursor, trans-[OsCl2(PPh3)3] (Fig. 8 ). The complexes promote the catalytic hydrogenation of acetophenone under various conditions: some displayed efficient catalysis of the hydrogenation of acetophenone with H2 in ethanol under low pressure, some induced asymmetric hydrogenation of acetophenone, whilst some were involved in the catalytic hydride transfer for the hydrogenation of acetophenone. In all cases, the study underscores the interesting catalytic effects of diphosphine ligands and their metal complexes in the hydrogenation of ketones [68]. Similarly, some Ru(II) complexes of biaryl diphosphine ligands have been prepared according to the route illustrated in Scheme 7 . The catalytic potential of the complexes for the hydrogenation of ketone to alcohol was significant, with a high enantioselectivity (up to 98 % ee) [69]. Supporting the vast multi-dimensional catalytic applications of diphosphines and their analogues, some enantiopure dissymmetrical diphosphines with atropisometric axes in their molecular architecture have been recently documented. The experimental mechanistic assessments and density functional theory (DFT) indicated that the compounds are potential catalysts for an asymmetric hydrogenation of imines, enhancing the enantioselectivity of the chiral amines under mild conditions [70]. Some monohydride-dichloride Rh(III) complexes of diphosphine ligands were also reported as promising catalysts for asymmetric hydrogenation of non-functionalized olefins [71]. In another report, some halide-bridged dinuclear iridium(III) complexes of chiral diphosphine ligands reportedly showed an interesting catalytic effect on the asymmetric hydrogenation of ketones and simple olefins. In addition to the catalytic effects, the complexes were highly stable in air/moisture, making them suitable for the asymmetric reactions [20]. Furthermore, on the catalytic versatility of diphosphine ligands in hydrogenation reactions, two diastereomeric biaryl diphosphine ligands with chiral centres, ((2R,2′R,4R,4′R,5aR,7′S,9aS)-2,2′,4,4′-tetramethyl-3,3′,4,4′,5a,7′,8′,9a-octahydro-2H,2′H-[6,6′-bibenzo[b][1,4]dioxepine]−7,7′-diyl)bis(diphenylphosphane) (DL13) and ((2R,2′R,4R,4′R,5′aS,6S,7R,9′aR)-2,2′,4,4′-tetramethyl-3,3′,4,4′,5a,5′a,6,7,8,9,9a,9′a-dodecahydro-2H,2′H-[6,6′-bibenzo[b][1,4]dioxepine]−7,7′-diyl)bis(diphenylphosphane) (DL14) (Fig. 9 ) as well as their corresponding ruthenium complexes [RuCl(p-cymene)L1]Cl and [RuCl(p-cymene)L2]Cl were synthesized by Qiu and co-workers. Upon evaluation, the complexes displayed efficient catalytic effects in the hydrogenation of propenoic acid and ketoester derivatives. The enhanced chirality of the diphosphine ligands was significantly influential in the impressive efficiency and enantioselectivity of the catalysts [72]. Huo et al. in 2021 reported the proficiency of cobalt(II) in complex with amine(imine)diphosphine for asymmetric catalytic transfer hydrogenation of ketones in a base-activated 2-propanolisopropanol as a solvent under mild conditions [73]. Similarly, the potential of some rhodium(III) complexes bearing chelating diphosphine ligands has been evaluated for catalytic transfer hydrogenation of ketone, specifically fluoroacetophenone. The catalytic activity of the rhodium(III) centre during the hydrogenation process was reportedly enhanced significantly by the presence of the diphosphine ligands by TON and TOF numbers of up to 4000 h-1 and 1000 h-1, respectively, compared to the phosphine-free ligand/rhodium complexes [74]. Abbas and co-workers documented an interesting Rh-catalytic asymmetric hydrogenation of functionalized olefins by some novel chiral ferrocene/indole-based diphosphine ligands (Fig. 10 ). The synthesised compounds were observed to display a remarkable enantioselectivity in the Rh-catalysed hydrogenation of enamides, ethyl (Z)-acetamidocinnamate and diethyl itaconate [24]. 11 Factors affecting the applicability of diphosphine catalysts in industrial production of C2+ chemicals The shreds of evidence above show that diphosphine ligands and their metal-coordinated hybrids are efficient catalysts for transfer hydrogenation of various classes of carbonyl organic compounds in addition to CO2. Although the structure-assisted high enantioselectivity and hydricity recorded for diphosphine analogues interestingly charts the path to mitigating some of the challenges associated with CO2 hydrogenation, including selectivity for desired products, kinetic and thermodynamic barriers, and performance-based catalytic design. However, other challenges that are generally associated with the catalytic conversion/hydrogenation of CO2, such as difficulty in process condition control, catalytic deactivation during harsh industrial conditions, removal of impurities, scaling up for commercialization, cost effectiveness and unravelling the multi-step reaction mechanisms involved, and recoverability challenge [75–81], also affect the applicability of diphosphine analogues, especially during industrial-scale production of C2+ chemicals. Although the introduction of heterogeneous diphosphine systems, such as diphosphine-metal hybrids, has abrogated some of the challenges and supports their suitability in these regards. For instance, the applicability of diphosphine ligands for the catalytic reduction of CO2 to HCs, olefin and LPG in homogeneous systems remains challenging due to several complexities such as tandem catalysis via the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, specificity of products, complex four-electron transformation and general industrial viability, all of which are more favoured heterogeneous catalysis [82,83]. Generally, opportunities emanating from nanotechnology by aiding the control of molecules in terms of particle composition, shape, size and morphology have reportedly promoted the development of highly performing catalytic materials. Designing the materials into nanoforms has been demonstrated to offer easy recovery, longer lifespan and enhanced catalytic effects overall [84,85]. Thus, considering the formulation of the identified potential diphosphine catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation on the nanoscale portrays a pattern of modern science for effective and sustainable material production and utilisation. In addition, rational design of heterogeneous analogues such as diphosphine-metal systems could synergistically advance product selectivity, recoverability and incorporation of computational approaches, and in-situ characterisation could promote multi-scale production modelling [86,77,87,88]). The understanding of the kinetics and dynamics of the mechanisms of the process remains underexplored. Although DFT has been extensively applied to study the mechanistic kinetics and pathways of the CO2 hydrogenation by phosphine and non-phosphine metal-based catalysts such as Ru-MACHO [89,90], Mn(I)- and Mn(II)-PN/PNP complexes [91,92], and Fe-complex catalysts [93]. Some other computational methods, such as the grand canonical Monte Carlo simulation, time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) and partial density of states (PDOS) calculation, have also been reportedly employed to study the mechanistic catalytic effects of other metal organic frameworks on CO2 hydrogenation, computationally in addition to experiments [94]. However, the application of more sophisticated computational methods such as some popular artificial intelligence (AI) tools including machine learning (ML), neural networks (NN) and deep learning (DL) to further understand the mechanisms and dynamisms, and discover new catalysts for efficient CO2 reduction is attracting scientific interests, recently [95–98]. Relevantly, these tools can be used to design new diphosphine ligands for enhanced catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 from chemical libraries through scaffold hopping and high-throughput screening. 12 Conclusion and perspectives Carbon dioxide emissions remain inevitable from human daily activities, ranging from domestic to industrial, and other natural phenomena. Its accumulation in the atmosphere could endanger some obnoxious consequences on the global environment, including global warming, acidic rainfall, ocean acidification, air pollution, and climate change. Therefore, exploring scientific efforts for converting CO2 to other chemical utilities for societal development through processes such as CO2 hydrogenation has become necessary. This process is usually characterised by a high energy demand, and the challenge is often mitigated by the application of ideal catalysts. This review surveys the proficiency of diphosphine chemical analogues for catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 and highlights some essential products of the process. Diphosphine analogues in various molecular forms, such as small molecules, dimerised hybrids. Ferrocenes and complexes with metals such as nickel, cobalt, palladium, rhodium, ruthenium, and iridium represent potential catalysts for asymmetric CO2 hydrogenation. The highlighted diphosphine derivatives display good enantioselectivity and hydricity that promote catalytic effects on the hydrogenation of CO2. They reportedly demonstrate interesting potential to produce green fuels, chemical building blocks, and industrial feedstock such as carboxylic acids and carboxylates (e.g. formic acid, formate, acetic acid and acetate), alcohols (e.g. methanol, ethanol), ketones and ketoesters, hydrocarbons (HCs, e.g. methane, benzene), olefins and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). Although their applicability for the catalytic reduction of CO2 to HCs, olefin and LPG remains challenging due to several factors such as tandem catalysis via the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, specificity of products and industrial viability, all of which require heterogeneous catalysis. In addition, some of the diphosphine chemical analogues are also applicable for other similar processes, such as hydrogenation of α- and β-ketones, acylophenone, functionalized olefins such as enamides, ethyl acetamidocinnamate, and itaconates. Although the structure-assisted high enantioselectivity and hydricity recorded for diphosphine analogues interestingly charts the path to mitigating some of the challenges associated with CO2 hydrogenation, including selectivity for desired products, kinetic and thermodynamic barriers, and performance-based catalytic design. However, other challenges associated with the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2, such as difficulty in process condition control, catalytic deactivation, removal of impurities, scaling up for commercialisation, and cost, also affect the applicability of diphosphine analogues. Suggestively, some of these limitations could be sustainably improved by redesigning the remarkable diphosphine compounds into nano forms utilising the trending nanotechnology. Moreover, detailed mechanisms of CO2 hydrogenation by diphosphine catalysts, including the steps, molecular species involved, and their favourable conditions, remain unbundled, and all these require further scientific attention. Summarily, this review relevantly models the opportunities for solving global challenges such as green energy sustainability, environmental sustainability, technological innovation, industrial production and promoting human well-being. It also demonstrates a viable approach to achieve the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 6–9, 12 and 13 for further scientific attention. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic conversion of the atmospheric CO2 to essential chemicals such as fuels and industrial feeds has become a subject of much interest due to its potential to meet sustainable global commodity and energy demands from a presumably environmental threats. Among the suitable catalysts for the multidimensional processes involved in the conversion, diphosphine ligands and their molecular analogues have been widely explored, and their potential for such responses is remarkable. Thus, this review surveys the reports on structure-related catalytic performances of various molecular analogues of diphosphine ligands in the conversion of CO2 into other chemical utilities. The analogues have been documented in various molecular forms, such as small molecules, dimerised hybrids. Ferrocenes and in complexes with metals such as nickel, cobalt, rhodium, rhenium, and iridium. The highlighted derivatives, such as DL01-DL14, display good enantioselectivity and hydricity that support catalytic effects on the hydrogenation of CO2 and other organocompounds. They reportedly demonstrate interesting potential to produce green fuels, chemical building blocks, and industrial feedstock such as carboxylic acids and carboxylates (e.g. formic acid, formate, acetic acid), alcohols (e.g. methanol, ethanol), ketones and ketoesters, olefins and hydrocarbon fuels. In addition, some of the diphosphine chemical analogues are also applicable for other similar processes, such as the hydrogenation of α- and β-ketones, acetophenone, functionalized olefins such as enamides, ethyl acetamidocinnamate, and itaconates. This overview promotes the applicability of diphosphine analogues as viable catalysts for converting CO2 into other chemical utilities amenable to further scientific efforts.
